title: Must Read: Haider Ackermann Drops Second Snow Goose Collection, Immigration Raids in L.A. Strike Fear Into Fashion Industry

text: Plus, Tyler, The Creator reimagines Converse Originals styles for latest collection.Photo: Willy Vanderperre/Courtesy of Canada GooseThese are the stories making headlines in fashion on Thursday.Haider Ackermann drops second Snow Goose collectionHaider Ackermann, creative director of Canada Goose, has released his second capsule collection for the brand's heritage label Snow Goose. "I wanted to peel away the layers with this campaign — of clothing, of convention, of expectation — to resist the predictable," the designer said in a press release. The 30-piece unisex lineup features fluorescent neon track pants that zip off into shorts, two-toned barrel cargos, T-shirts with vivid prints of tactical gear and more. {Fashionista inbox}Immigration raids in L.A. strike fear into fashion industryImmigrant workers in Los Angeles' garment industry were among those detained in the raids incited by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) last week, instilling a deep sense of fear and overwhelm within the community. "They're scared and terrified. I want people to understand who they're going after is not criminals. These are real people with families," one L.A.-based brand owner told Vogue Business. Out of the more than 300,000 workers producing clothing and shoes in the United States, more than one-third are immigrants. {Vogue Business}Tyler, The Creator reimagines Converse Originals styles for latest collectionPhoto: Courtesy of ConverseFor his latest drop with Converse, Tyler, The Creator revived two styles from the shoe brand's archive through 1908, a program built to revitalize silhouettes from the company's past.  The two styles — the Naut-1 (a boating shoe originally released in the early 1970s) and the Coach Jogger (a performance track shoe that first debuted in 1976) — will be globally available starting June 20. {Fashionista inbox}Dua Lipa covers British Vogue's July 2025 coverDua Lipa on the cover of British Vogue's July 2025 issue.Photo: David Sims/Courtesy of Condé NastScroll to ContinueRecommended ArticlesDua Lipa is British Vogue's July 2025 cover star. The singer — photographed by David Sims and styled by Camilla Nickerson — poses in Miu Miu, Givenchy by Sarah Burton, Calvin Klein Collection and Dilara Findikoglu throughout the spread. In the accompanying interview with Gaby Wood, Lipa discusses her engagement to actor Callum Turner, selling out Wembley Stadium (twice) and expanding her editorial platform Service95. {British Vogue}Outdoor Voices founder raises Series A for new start-upTy Haney, founder of Outdoor Voices, announced Wednesday that her new venture, Try Your Best, raised $11 million in a Series A funding round led by Offline Ventures and Strobe Ventures. Try Your Best — which currently works with companies like Rare Beauty and Glossier — rewards consumers for engaging with their favorite brands. {Business of Fashion}Victoria's Secret expects $10 million loss in Q2 operating income after cybersecurity breachAfter facing a major cybersecurity breach that halted sales company-wide over Memorial Day Weekend, Victoria's Secret reported that it expects $10 million from Q2 to come out of its operating income, excluding any insurance payment. {Victoria's Secret}LoveShackFancy drops first menswear capsule collectionOn Thursday, LoveShackFancy announced Mr Fancy, the brand's first-ever menswear release. Including vintage-inspired swim trunks, floral button-downs and sweatshirts, the full capsule is available to shop now at loveshackfancy.com. {Fashionista inbox}Please note: Occasionally, we use affiliate links on our site. html:
Plus, Tyler, The Creator reimagines Converse Originals styles for latest collection.

These are the stories making headlines in fashion on Thursday.

Haider Ackermann drops second Snow Goose collection

Haider Ackermann, creative director of Canada Goose, has released his second capsule collection for the brand's heritage label Snow Goose. "I wanted to peel away the layers with this campaign — of clothing, of convention, of expectation — to resist the predictable," the designer said in a press release. The 30-piece unisex lineup features fluorescent neon track pants that zip off into shorts, two-toned barrel cargos, T-shirts with vivid prints of tactical gear and more. {Fashionista inbox}

Immigration raids in L.A. strike fear into fashion industry

Immigrant workers in Los Angeles' garment industry were among those detained in the raids incited by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) last week, instilling a deep sense of fear and overwhelm within the community. "They're scared and terrified. I want people to understand who they're going after is not criminals. These are real people with families," one L.A.-based brand owner told Vogue Business. Out of the more than 300,000 workers producing clothing and shoes in the United States, more than one-third are immigrants. {Vogue Business}

Tyler, The Creator reimagines Converse Originals styles for latest collection

For his latest drop with Converse, Tyler, The Creator revived two styles from the shoe brand's archive through 1908, a program built to revitalize silhouettes from the company's past.  The two styles — the Naut-1 (a boating shoe originally released in the early 1970s) and the Coach Jogger (a performance track shoe that first debuted in 1976) — will be globally available starting June 20. {Fashionista inbox}

Dua Lipa covers British Vogue's July 2025 cover

Scroll to Continue

Recommended Articles

Dua Lipa is British Vogue's July 2025 cover star. The singer — photographed by David Sims and styled by Camilla Nickerson — poses in Miu Miu, Givenchy by Sarah Burton, Calvin Klein Collection and Dilara Findikoglu throughout the spread. In the accompanying interview with Gaby Wood, Lipa discusses her engagement to actor Callum Turner, selling out Wembley Stadium (twice) and expanding her editorial platform Service95. {British Vogue}

Outdoor Voices founder raises Series A for new start-up

Ty Haney, founder of Outdoor Voices, announced Wednesday that her new venture, Try Your Best, raised $11 million in a Series A funding round led by Offline Ventures and Strobe Ventures. Try Your Best — which currently works with companies like Rare Beauty and Glossier — rewards consumers for engaging with their favorite brands. {Business of Fashion}

Victoria's Secret expects $10 million loss in Q2 operating income after cybersecurity breach

After facing a major cybersecurity breach that halted sales company-wide over Memorial Day Weekend, Victoria's Secret reported that it expects $10 million from Q2 to come out of its operating income, excluding any insurance payment. {Victoria's Secret}

LoveShackFancy drops first menswear capsule collection

On Thursday, LoveShackFancy announced Mr Fancy, the brand's first-ever menswear release. Including vintage-inspired swim trunks, floral button-downs and sweatshirts, the full capsule is available to shop now at loveshackfancy.com. {Fashionista inbox}

Please note: Occasionally, we use affiliate links on our site. This in no way affects our editorial decision-making.

We offer unique services and partnership opportunities for brands big and small to get in front of Fashionista’s community of 1M readers. Learn More.
